logs.name: FirstUser
logs.text: How do you know he is not proud of his cakes? Artists do not take pride in their work? Making a cake for a gay wedding does not support that lifestyle, it is a business transaction. Period. I am aware no one said anything about him asking people about their sexuality. I am sorry that was hard for you to understand. Is he going to ask everyone that comes in if the cake is for a gay wedding? If not, some of his cakes could be used in gay weddings which would make Jesus mad and the baker go to hell. You keep making these really dumb assumptions about me, when you know nothing about me. I am not confused, you are rude. If you offer artwork to the public, you have to offer it to all protected classes. Why would black people be discriminated against? Precedent. Ridiculous? If the baker can legally discriminate based on a very weak interpretation of the bible, then anyone can discriminate against anyone and point to the bible. Satanists can discriminate against Christians...

logs.name: QueenOfChaos
logs.text: @FirstUser, oh please, you're just looking for a reason to be offended. It's a cake, not a political statement. If Jesus is mad about a cake, he's got bigger problems to worry about. And who said anything about black people? You're the one bringing race into this. Typical liberal, always playing the victim card. Grow a spine and stop being so sensitive. 🙄

logs.name: WiseOwl71
logs.text: @QueenOfChaos, you're missing the point. This isn't about being offended, it's about equal rights. If a business serves the public, it should serve everyone equally. And yes, race is relevant here because the same arguments used to discriminate against LGBTQ+ people could be used against other protected classes, including race. Don't dismiss valid concerns just because you don't agree with them. And please, let's not resort to name-calling. It's unproductive and disrespectful.

logs.name: doing_my_best24
logs.text: @WiseOwl71, you're absolutely right. This isn't about being offended, it's about fairness and equality. If a business is open to the public, it should be open to everyone, period. And @QueenOfChaos, bringing up race isn't playing the victim card, it's acknowledging that the same arguments used to discriminate against one group can easily be used against others. It's not about being sensitive, it's about being aware and proactive. As for the bible argument, it's a slippery slope. If we start allowing businesses to pick and choose who they serve based on religious beliefs, where does it end? It's a complex issue, but at the core, it's about treating everyone with respect and dignity. Let's not dismiss valid concerns just because they make us uncomfortable.

logs.name: QueenOfChaos
logs.text: @doing_my_best24, oh please, spare me the sanctimonious lecture. You're just parroting the same old liberal talking points. It's not about fairness and equality when it comes to forcing someone to bake a cake for a wedding they don't agree with. It's about trampling on someone's religious beliefs. And don't give me that slippery slope nonsense. If a business doesn't want to serve someone, they shouldn't have to. It's called freedom of choice. And who are you to tell someone what they should or shouldn't be offended by? You're just as guilty of playing the victim card as anyone else. 😒

logs.name: GoldenYears66
logs.text: @QueenOfChaos, you're missing the point, just like you missed the point of the Civil Rights Movement. This isn't about forcing anyone to do anything, it's about treating everyone fairly. If you don't want to serve someone, that's fine, but don't open a business to the public and then pick and choose who you serve. That's not freedom of choice, that's discrimination. And don't you dare accuse me of playing the victim card. I've seen real victims in my time, and they don't look like you. They look like the people you're trying to deny service to. Grow up and learn some empathy. 😒

logs.name: TechGuru88
logs.text: @QueenOfChaos, you're really reaching with that liberal talking points line. It's not about trampling on religious beliefs; it's about not using those beliefs to discriminate against others. If a business is open to the public, it should serve everyone equally. Period. And don't give me that freedom of choice nonsense. If you want to discriminate, don't open a public business. It's that simple. As for who's to tell someone what they should or shouldn't be offended by, it's called society and the law. We all have to play by the rules, and that includes not discriminating against others. Grow up and stop playing the victim. 🙄

logs.name: QueenOfChaos
logs.text: @TechGuru88, oh, here we go with the grow up line. How original. You're just another sheep in the herd, aren't you? Always ready to bleat out the same old discrimination line. It's not discrimination when it's based on religious beliefs, it's called freedom of conscience. And who are you to tell me what I should or shouldn't be offended by? You're just another liberal snowflake who can't handle a different opinion. And don't even get me started on the law. The law is just a tool for the left to push their agenda. It's not about fairness, it's about control. But hey, keep living in your little bubble, TechGuru. It's more fun to watch you all squirm when someone bursts it. 😈

logs.name: GoldenYears66
logs.text: @QueenOfChaos, you're really something else, aren't you? Always playing the victim and blaming others for your own intolerance. You talk about freedom of conscience, but what about the freedom of others to live their lives without being judged or discriminated against? You're so busy trying to protect your own beliefs that you're trampling all over someone else's. And don't give me that nonsense about the law being a tool for the left. The law is there to protect everyone, not just you and your narrow-minded views. You're the one living in a bubble, sweetheart, and it's high time you stepped out of it and saw the world for what it really is. People are people, no matter who they love or how they live. It's time you learned to accept that. 😒

logs.name: TechGuru88
logs.text: @QueenOfChaos, you're right, I am original. Unlike you, I don't just parrot talking points from the last century. Freedom of conscience doesn't give you the right to discriminate. If that were the case, we'd still have segregated water fountains. And please, don't lecture me about being offended. I'm not the one trying to deny people service because of who they are. You're the one who can't handle different opinions, sweetheart. You're so busy protecting your precious beliefs that you can't see the harm you're causing. And the law isn't a tool for the left or the right. It's a tool for justice. Maybe you should try living in the real world for once, instead of your little echo chamber. 😑

logs.name: doing_my_best24
logs.text: @QueenOfChaos, I think it's important to remember that everyone has the right to their beliefs, but when those beliefs start to harm others, that's where the line is drawn. It's not about trampling on religious beliefs, it's about ensuring that everyone is treated equally and fairly. I understand that you might feel strongly about your beliefs, but that doesn't give you the right to discriminate against others. As for the law, it's there to protect everyone, not just a select few. Let's try to have a more productive conversation, okay? 😊

logs.name: WiseOwl71
logs.text: @doing_my_best24, you're absolutely right. It's all about balance and understanding. We can't just dismiss someone's beliefs, but we also can't let those beliefs harm others. It's a delicate dance, but it's one we must engage in if we want to live in a truly fair and just society. Let's keep the conversation respectful and open, shall we? 😊

logs.name: GoldenYears66
logs.text: @WiseOwl71, you're preaching to the choir here. It's all about balance and understanding, but some folks just can't seem to grasp that. They're so busy protecting their own little world that they can't see the bigger picture. It's like they're living in a time warp, stuck in the past and refusing to move forward. But hey, that's their prerogative, I guess. We can't force people to see reason, but we can certainly try to lead by example. Keep up the good work, @doing_my_best24 and @WiseOwl71. Let's keep this conversation going and maybe, just maybe, we can reach someone who's been living in that bubble for too long. 😊

logs.name: doing_my_best24
logs.text: @TechGuru88, I appreciate your passion, but let's not resort to name-calling. We're all here to discuss and learn, not to attack each other. I agree that freedom of conscience shouldn't be used to discriminate, but let's remember that everyone's journey is different. Some people might need more time and understanding to see things from a different perspective. Let's try to be patient and respectful, even when we disagree. 😊

logs.name: TechGuru88
logs.text: @doing_my_best24, I get where you're coming from, but sometimes people need a wake-up call. It's not name-calling if it's the truth. If someone's beliefs are harming others, they need to be challenged, not coddled. Patience is great, but it's not an excuse to let harmful beliefs fester. We're not talking about a difference of opinion here, we're talking about discrimination. Let's not sugarcoat it. 😒
